title: Electric Potential - sphere with charge density Cr

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A solid insulating sphere has a radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, as shown in the cross-sectional view in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and is electrically charged with a net charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math>. The sphere’s charge density is nonuniform and given by the equation <math alttext="rho equals C times lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>C</mi><mi>r</mi></math>, where <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math> is a positive constant and <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> is the distance from the center of the sphere. (a)i. Taking the electric potential to be zero at the center of the sphere, derive an expression for the electric potential at a point inside the sphere that is a distance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> from the center. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

A solid insulating sphere has a radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, as shown in the cross-sectional view in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and is electrically charged with a net charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math>. The sphere’s charge density is nonuniform and given by the equation <math alttext="rho equals C times lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>C</mi><mi>r</mi></math>, where <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math> is a positive constant and <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> is the distance from the center of the sphere. (a)i. Taking the electric potential to be zero at the center of the sphere, derive an expression for the electric potential at a point inside the sphere that is a distance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> from the center. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> shows the same cross-sectional view of the sphere as well as a point labeled <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> in the interior of the sphere.ii. On Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a line or curve representing an equipotential surface that includes Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>.

iii. On Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, indicate the direction of the electric field, if any, at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>. If the field is zero at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>, write “<math alttext="E equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>” next to Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>. Otherwise, represent the field direction with an arrow that starts on Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math> and points in the direction of the field.

A narrow hole is drilled in the sphere from the surface radially inward to the sphere’s center. The hole does not significantly change the electric field or the electric potential within the sphere. A positively charged particle of charge <math alttext="q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math> and mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is then placed at the sphere’s center and given an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> toward the sphere’s surface and along the direction of the hole.(b) Derive an expression for the speed of the charged particle when it reaches the surface of the sphere. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math>, <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.
